summary: This is an FBI 302 form documenting a proffer interview with an individual (redacted) who worked for Jeffrey Epstein from 2004-2006. The witness describes the roles and relationship of Ghislaine Maxwell, details about Epstein's daily massages, the storage of intimate photographs, and instructions to remove contact books and computers from properties following an investigation.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Described as overseeing Epstein's operations, managing his properties, having a 'family-like' relationship with him, and historically procuring girls for sexual activities. She maintained her own contact books and office.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject. The witness describes his daily routine of two massages, his instructions to staff, his relationship with Maxwell, and his possession of binders containing intimate photographs of women.

persons.name: Jean Luc Brunel
persons.context: Mentioned briefly as having sent a strange message that Maxwell found funny and possibly assisted in crafting.

persons.name: Les Wexner
persons.context: Epstein and the witness went to see him. Maxwell was present with a group of women and was 'chewing them out.'

persons.name: Janusz Banasiak
persons.context: A new house manager in Palm Beach who impressed Maxwell by bringing in fresh flowers. He later helped the witness gather items from the Palm Beach house.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.context: Mentioned as someone who may have confirmed massage appointments for Epstein.

persons.name: Eva Dubin
persons.context: Described as an ex-girlfriend whom Epstein kept around, considered 'like family' alongside Maxwell.

persons.name: Mark
persons.context: The IT person staff would call for computer issues; the witness thought he might have knowledge of the database (Citrix) they used.

connections.description: Described as having a 'family-like' relationship. Epstein stated that when they dated, Maxwell would bring girls for threesomes. Maxwell acted as a manager of his properties and operations.
Maxwell was impressed with Banasiak when he started as house manager. He later assisted a witness in gathering items at her/Epstein's direction.
Epstein and the witness went to see Wexner. The context suggests a personal or business relationship.
Described as an ex-girlfriend whom Epstein kept around his life, considered 'like family'.
Maxwell found a strange message from Brunel funny and either assisted or directed how to respond to it.

events.title: Witness's Employment Period
events.description: The witness worked for Jeffrey Epstein during this period, initially doing informal tasks and later working as an assistant involved in scheduling and logistics.

events.title: Removal of Evidence from Palm Beach
events.description: Around October 6 (the day before the witness's birthday), the witness was directed by Epstein and a redacted individual to go to the Palm Beach house to meet an investigator and hand over contact books and computers. Janusz Banasiak assisted.

events.title: Removal of Evidence from Epstein's Island
events.description: A couple weeks after the Palm Beach removal, the witness was instructed to remove contact books from Epstein's island and take them to New York.

events.title: Proffer Interview
events.description: The witness was interviewed pursuant to a proffer agreement via video conference, providing information about Epstein and Maxwell's operations.

keyFacts: Epstein received two massages per day, and it was 'common knowledge' among staff. Maxwell was aware and, on at least one occasion in New Mexico, instructed staff to find a 'pretty' masseuse for him.

Large binders containing intimate, topless 'model-type' photographs of women (some potentially underage) were stored in Maxwell's New York office and displayed in Epstein's homes. The photos were printed on a commercial printer at Maxwell's house.

Epstein and Maxwell maintained separate contact books (colorful for Epstein, black for Maxwell) which contained massage contacts organized by location. The witness was tasked with updating Epstein's books.

Following an incident Epstein described as 'something happened to his detriment' related to 'visas and immigration,' the witness was instructed to remove contact books and computers from the Palm Beach house and later from the island to prevent their discovery.
Epstein told the witness that when he and Maxwell dated, Maxwell would bring girls for threesomes, which the witness understood to be for sexual activities.
